newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombia to fight pipeline bombings with ads.
newsitem.headline: Colombia to fight pipeline bombings with ads.

text.p: Colombia's state-run oil company Ecopetrol will launch a nationwide advertising campaign to help safeguard the country's main oil pipeline, a frequent target of leftist rebel attacks over the last 10 years.
Ecopetrol said in a statement that multinationals Occidental Petroleum Corp and the Colombian subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell would help finance the publicity drive.

"The three owners of the pipeline have designed a communications strategy with which we hope to awaken the conscience of the country about the economic, social and environmental effects of dynamite attacks against oil pipelines," Ecopetrol said.
An Ecopetrol spokeswoman declined to say on Monday how much the TV, radio and newspaper campaign would cost but said it was scheduled to be launched before the end of February.

The National Liberation Army (ELN), Colombia's second largest guerrilla force formed by radical Roman Catholic priests in the mid-1960s, has dynamited the pipeline 426 times since it opened in 1986. In 1996 alone the pipeline was attacked 47 times.

More than 1.4 million barrels of crude have been lost over a 10-year period in the attacks on the pipeline that runs from Cano Limon, in eastern Colombia, to the Caribbean coast terminal at Covenas. Ecopetrol said the combined cost of repairs and lost production amounted to about $1.8 billion.
At least 10 members of the main oil workers' union USO have been arrested in the last two months and charged with carrying out the pipeline bombings in league with the ELN.
